article_title: Pope tarnished his authenticity by stepping into our culture wars
article_text:
Pope tarnished his authenticity by stepping into our culture wars

Photo: Timothy D. Easley, Associated Press Kentucky county clerk Kim Davis met with Pope Francis.

The extensive, at times nonstop, media coverage of the pope’s visit was justified in that as the head of 1.2 billion Catholics, Francis is a leader of spiritual depth, humble style, personal charm and unlimited compassion for the poor, vulnerable and marginalized among us. It was assumed that Francis would stay out of the culture wars, but that didn’t happen.

article_metadata.sailthru.author: By Brian Cahill
article_metadata.description: The extensive, at times nonstop, media coverage of the pope’s visit was justified in that as the head of 1.2 billion Catholics, Francis is a leader of spiritual depth, humble style, personal charm and unlimited compassion for the poor, vulnerable and marginalized among us.  First the pope visited the Little Sisters of the Poor, who just happen to be the only order of American nuns resisting the latest Obama compromise regarding the contraception mandate of the Affordable Care Act.  [...] departing from his custom of transparency, Francis had a secret meeting with Kim Davis, the Kentucky county clerk who was jailed for refusing to issue same-sex marriage certificates.  [...] try telling that to the Catholic LGBT advocacy organizations, all of whom were excluded from the World Meeting on Families by Philadelphia Archbishop Charles Chaput.  [...] when I have the urge to bolt, I’ll keep remembering what the great Catholic theologian Hans Kung said when he was asked why one should stay in such a flawed church: “We ourselves are the Church and should not confuse it with its machinery and administrators, still less leave the latter to shape the community.”
